item.title: Chloe add a quote by Jorge Luis Borges
item.description: "I have always imagined that Paradise will be a kind of library." -- Jorge Luis Borges

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Carl Gustav Jung
item.description: "I am not what happened to me, I am what I choose to become." -- Carl Gustav Jung

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Henry Miller
item.description: "A man should begin with his own times. He should become acquainted first of all with the world in which he is living and participating. He should not be afraid of reading too much or too little. He should take his reading as he does his food or his exercise. The good reader will gravitate to the good books. He will discover from his contemporaries what is inspiring or fecundating, or merely enjoyable, in past literature. He should have the pleasure of making these discoveries on his own, in his own way. What has worth, charm, beauty, wisdom, cannot be lost or forgotten. But things can lose all value, all charm and appeal, if one is dragged to them by the scalp." -- Henry Miller

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Chuck Palahniuk
item.description: "When did the future switch from being a promise to being a threat?" -- Chuck Palahniuk

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Charles Bukowski
item.description: "those who escape hell however never talk about it and nothing much bothers them after that." -- Charles Bukowski

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Louis de Bernieres
item.description: "Love is a temporary madness, it erupts like volcanoes and then subsides. And when it subsides, you have to make a decision. You have to work out whether your roots have so entwined together that it is inconceivable that you should ever part. Because this is what love is. Love is not breathlessness, it is not excitement, it is not the promulgation of promises of eternal passion, it is not the desire to mate every second minute of the day, it is not lying awake at night imagining that he is kissing every cranny of your body. No, don't blush, I am telling you some truths. That is just being "in love", which any fool can do. Love itself is what is left over when being in love has burned away, and this is both an art and a fortunate accident." -- Louis de Bernieres

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Carson McCullers
item.description: "Next to music, beer was best." -- Carson McCullers

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Douglas Adams
item.description: "I love deadlines. I love the whooshing noise they make as they go by." -- Douglas Adams

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Henry Ward Beecherr
item.description: "Where is human nature so weak as in the bookstore?" -- Henry Ward Beecherr

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description: "Facts do not cease to exist because they are ignored." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Fyodor Dostoyevsky
item.description: "The more stupid one is, the closer one is to reality. The more stupid one is, the clearer one is. Stupidity is brief and artless, while intelligence squirms and hides itself. Intelligence is unprincipled, but stupidity is honest and straightforward." -- Fyodor Dostoyevsky

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Arundhati Roy
item.description:
"...the secret of the Great Stories is that they <i>have</i> no secrets. The Great Stories are the ones you have heard and want to hear again. The ones you can enter anywhere and inhabit comfortably. They don’t deceive you with thrills and trick endings. They don’t surprise you with the unforeseen. They are as familiar as the house you live in. Or the smell of your lover’s skin. You know how they end, yet you listen as though you don’t. In the way that although you know that one day you will die, you live as though you won’t. In the Great Stories you know who lives, who dies, who finds love, who doesn’t. And yet you want to know again.
<i>That</i> is their mystery and their magic." -- Arundhati Roy

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Christopher Moore
item.description: "Don't be ridiculous, Charlie, people love the parents who beat their kids in department stores. It's the ones who just let their kids wreak havoc that everybody hates." -- Christopher Moore

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Friedrich Nietzsche
item.description: "Without music, life would be a mistake." -- Friedrich Nietzsche

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Jorge Luis Borges
item.description: "Let others pride themselves about how many pages they have written; I'd rather boast about the ones I've read." -- Jorge Luis Borges

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Lance Carbuncle
item.description: "People who don't know me well enough might say I'm delusional and paranoid, but they're just out to get me." -- Lance Carbuncle

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Hermann Hesse
item.description: "One never reaches home,' she said. 'But where paths that have an affinity for each other intersect, the whole world looks like home, for a time." -- Hermann Hesse

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Bill Hicks
item.description: "The worst kind of non-smokers are the ones that come up to you and cough. That's pretty fucking cruel isn't it? Do you go up to cripples and dance too?" -- Bill Hicks

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Neil Gaiman
item.description: "[D]on't ever apologize to an author for buying something in paperback, or taking it out from a library (that's what they're there for. Use your library). Don't apologize to this author for buying books second hand, or getting them from bookcrossing or borrowing a friend's copy. What's important to me is that people read the books and enjoy them, and that, at some point in there, the book was bought by someone. And that people who like things, tell other people. The most important thing is that people read... " -- Neil Gaiman

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Edward Abbey
item.description: "We are slaves in the sense that we depend for our daily survival upon an expand-or-expire agro-industrial empire—a crackpot machine—that the specialists cannot comprehend and the managers cannot manage. Which is, furthermore, devouring world resources at an exponential rate. We are, most of us, dependent employees. …Edward Abbey (1927-1989) " -- Edward Abbey

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Terry Pratchett
item.description: "If you have enough book space, I don't want to talk to you." -- Terry Pratchett

item.title: Chloe add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "Friendship is born at that moment when one man says to another: "What! You too? I thought that no one but myself . . .&#34;" -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Fyodor Dostoevsky
item.description: "Right or wrong, it's very pleasant to break something from time to time." -- Fyodor Dostoevsky

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Paul Auster
item.description: "One should never underestimate the power of books." -- Paul Auster

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "I have never let my schooling interfere with my education." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Graham Greene
item.description: "But I'm a bad priest, you see. I know--from experience--how much beauty Satan carried down with him when he fell. Nobody ever said the fallen angels were the ugly ones. Oh, no, they were just as quick and light and . . ." -- Graham Greene

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Arnold Lobel
item.description: "Books to the ceiling, Books to the sky, My pile of books is a mile high. How I love them! How I need them! I'll have a long beard by the time I read them." -- Arnold Lobel

item.title: Chloe add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "Given the choice between the experience of pain and nothing, I would choose pain." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Chloe add a quote by Walker Percy
item.description: "For some time now the impression has been growing upon me that everyone is dead. It happens when I speak to people. In the middle of a sentence it will come over me: yes, beyond a doubt this is death. There is little to do but groan and make an excuse and slip away as quickly as one can. At such times it seems that the conversation is spoken by automatons who have no choice in what they say. I hear myself or someone else saying things like: "In my opinion the Russian people are a great people, but--" or "Yes, what you say about the hypocrisy of the North is unquestionably true. However--" and I think to myself: this is death. Lately it is all I can do to carry on such everyday conversations, because my cheek has developed a tendency to twitch of its own accord." -- Walker Percy
